articles.headline: Turkey Spends Freely Again, and Some Analysts Worry
articles.snippet: The country’s economy, which crashed in 1994 and 2001 and was set back by the global financial crisis, is showing signs of overheating, fueled by consumer spending.
articles.abstract: The country’s economy, which crashed in 1994 and 2001 and was set back by the global financial crisis, is showing signs of overheating, fueled by consumer spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Is Turkey’s booming economy ripe for a fall? It certainly looks that way.

articles.headline: M.I.T. Media Lab Names a New Director
articles.snippet: Joichi Ito is a 44-year-old Japanese venture capitalist who does not have a college degree but has worked with several Internet organizations and invested in start-ups.
articles.abstract: Joichi Ito is a 44-year-old Japanese venture capitalist who does not have a college degree but has worked with several Internet organizations and invested in start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: For centuries diplomas have been synonymous with the nation’s universities.

articles.headline: Rivet Manufacturing Flaw Suspected in Jet’s Roof
articles.snippet: Investigators say they found rivet holes that were too big and appear to be misshapen from wear in a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 that peeled open in flight earlier this month.
articles.abstract: Investigators say they found rivet holes that were too big and appear to be misshapen from wear in a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 that peeled open in flight earlier this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators said Monday that they had discovered flaws in the riveting of the roof of the Southwest Airlines plane that tore open in flight on April 1, a finding that experts said probably showed manufacturing defects.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Law Firm Won’t Defend Marriage Act
articles.snippet: The law firm hired by the House to defend the Defense of Marriage Act withdrew amid pressure from gay rights activists.
articles.abstract: The law firm hired by the House to defend the Defense of Marriage Act withdrew amid pressure from gay rights activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The law firm hired by Republicans in the House of Representatives to defend the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act withdrew Monday amid pressure from gay rights groups. The decision prompted the resignation of a prominent partner, who said he intended to take the case with him to another law office.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Preserving a Market Symbol
articles.snippet: As a fight for ownership of the New York Stock Exchange continues, both bidders have pledged to preserve the 219-year-old capitalist symbol.
articles.abstract: As a fight for ownership of the New York Stock Exchange continues, both bidders have pledged to preserve the 219-year-old capitalist symbol.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to keeping the New York Stock Exchange’s trading floor open, Robert Greifeld makes a very unlikely savior.

articles.headline: Apple and Google Use Phone Data to Map the World
articles.snippet: Apple and Google use data collected from phones to improve their location services, which could lead to lucrative advertising.
articles.abstract: Apple and Google use data collected from phones to improve their location services, which could lead to lucrative advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — You may not know it, but if you carry a smartphone in your pocket, you are probably doing unpaid work for Apple or Google — and helping them eventually aim more advertising directly at you.

articles.headline: Public Pensions, Once Off Limits, Face Budget Cuts
articles.snippet: Officials in strapped states have begun looking for loopholes to cut retirement benefits for current employees.
articles.abstract: Officials in strapped states have begun looking for loopholes to cut retirement benefits for current employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an arbitrator ruled this month that Detroit could reduce the pensions being earned by its police sergeants and lieutenants, it put the struggling city at the forefront of a growing national debate over whether the pensions of current public workers can or should be reduced.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Dossier Shows Push for More Attacks After 9/11
articles.snippet: Saifullah Paracha was one of a small circle of Al Qaeda operatives who explored ways to follow up with new terror attacks, according to classified files.
articles.abstract: Saifullah Paracha was one of a small circle of Al Qaeda operatives who explored ways to follow up with new terror attacks, according to classified files.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He peers out from the photo in the classified file through heavy-framed spectacles, an owlish face with a graying beard and a half-smile. Saifullah Paracha, a successful businessman and for years a New York travel agent, appears to be the oldest of the 172 prisoners still held at the Guantánamo Bay prison. His dossier is among the most chilling.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Benjamin Weiser
